We must sever all ties with the genocidal apartheid state of Israel. "We must expel the ambassador and shut down the embassy, and stand with the Palestinian people until every inch of their land is free, from the river to the sea, a single democratic state with equal rights for all."

title: Your Party: Old infighting habits die hard at new left-wing party's acrimonious Liverpool conference
description: Anyone playing bingo with the left-wing lexicon would have been sure of a fully marked-off card by the close of Your Party's founding conference on the banks of the Mersey.
Author: Rob Powell
Headline: With its two figureheads seemingly at odds, the party's founding conference featured dated behaviour and predictable positional tensions, which nonetheless made for compelling political theatre.
Content:
Political correspondent
              @robpowellnews
 Anyone playing bingo with the left-wing lexicon would have been sure of a fully marked-off card by the close of Your Party's founding conference on the banks of the Mersey. Witch hunt - check. Sabotage and intimidation - check. Faceless unelected bureaucrats - HOUSE!  Bonus points were also on offer if you spotted the right-wing newspaper reporter forced to hang around outside the conference after a mysterious and unfixable error with his accreditation stopped him from accessing the venue. For a party painting itself as the face of the new left, there was plenty of dated behaviour during this two-day jamboree. A gauntlet of leafleters awaited all attendees from an extensive range of left-wing organisations. Your correspondent ended the gathering with literature from (deep breath) - the Revolutionary Communist Group, the Socialist Workers Party, the Socialist Unity Platform, the Socialist Equality Party, the Democratic Socialists, the Democratic Bloc, the Spartacist League, Workers Hammer, the Weekly Worker and, of course, the Morning Star. Tensions make compelling politics 
                  Your Party founder Zarah Sultana hits out at party 'witch hunts' and 'bullying'
                 
                  Jeremy Corbyn declines to call Zarah Sultana a friend as Your Party holds first conference
                 
                  Sultana accused by Corbyn allies of encouraging 'ultra leftists' to disrupt Your Party conference
                 This plethora of groupings led to some predictable positional tensions. At one point the Democratic Socialists - who had already split from the more formal Your Party grouping to align with Zarah Sultana's supporters - then split again, this time from Team Sultana, and called for members to reject the founding constitution and political statement that they had spent the past 24 hours trying to amend, only to then pivot one more time and encourage their base to vote in favour.  So - beyond the fact that this has been incredibly compelling politics - why do I relay all this to you? Well, it's because Your Party's analysis of its reason for being is a good one. A threat to Labour? There is political space for a new left-wing force that could inflict severe damage to Labour at the ballot box. But based on events this weekend, I can't say with confidence that force will be Your Party. There is obviously a huge amount of tension between the two most high-profile politicians in the party. Zarah Sultana spent much of the weekend directly accusing figures around Jeremy Corbyn of trying to drum out some of her supporters, even going as far as boycotting the first day of her own conference in protest at expulsions carried out on the eve of the event.  The Coventry South MP did insist the pair were friends, saying, "Jeremy came to my wedding." 'We're colleagues' But the former Labour leader seemed less sure. When asked the same question, he simply and - somewhat brutally - said "we're colleagues". As for where this goes now, the party is about to begin a process not of electing a leader, but a leadership committee - chaired by a rank-and-file member with four spots reserved for MPs and councillors. The idea is to hand more power over policy-making and whipping to the grassroots. The risk is that this new structure just becomes another venue for further falling out. If a camel is a horse designed by committee, could this "pioneering" leadership structure end up pleasing no one and angering everyone? This all matters more because the same 'modern left' electoral arena these guys are trying to occupy already has a new kid on the block in the slickly communicated and comparatively collegiate Green Party. Read more from Sky News:Why all the tension in Your Party?Committee to lead Your Party Many members in Liverpool spoke highly of Zack Polanski, with senior party figures and supporters alike open to the idea of exploring electoral pacts on a constituency-by-constituency basis. It's in this broader concept of a progressive alliance that Your Party's future may realistically lie in the long run. For as much as the comrades on the Mersey raged at Sir Keir Starmer, would they really let Nigel Farage slope into Downing Street in order to lash out at Labour? Maybe. Maybe not. Internecine warfare can come naturally to the left. And as we've learnt in Liverpool this weekend, old habits die hard.

title: Your Party votes to be led by members rather than single MP - avoiding Corbyn-Sultana battle
description: Your Party will be led by its members rather than a single MP, avoiding a battle between its two co-founders, Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana.
Author: Faye Brown
Headline: The decision is seen as a win for Zarah Sultana, who favoured collective leadership - but allies of Jeremy Corbyn say this is a missed opportunity for him to lead the party.
Content:
Political reporter
              @fayebrownSky
  Your Party will be led by its members rather than a single MP, avoiding a battle between its two co-founders, Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana. Members have voted for a collective leadership model rather than a single leadership model, by a margin of 51.6% to 48.4%. Politics Live: Chancellor denies lying about budget forecast  There was a big cheer as the result was announced to delegates gathered in Liverpool for the new movement's annual founding conference. However, one ally of Mr Corbyn told Sky News: "People have voted against utilising the biggest asset the party had - Jeremy." Your Party has been marred by factionalism between the two figureheads from the outset and had a single leadership model been picked, a big battle for the top job was expected. But many members told Sky News at the conference that because of the squabbling, they want Your Party to be led by the people rather than "personality icons". 
                  'Of course I didn't' lie about budget forecasts, chancellor tells Sky News - as Badenoch calls for her to resign
                 
                  Sir Keir Starmer to defend budget amid claims Rachel Reeves 'lied' about public finances
                 
                  Your Party founder Zarah Sultana hits out at party 'witch hunts' and 'bullying'
                 Collective leadership will see ordinary members who are not MPs elected to senior positions on a Central Executive Committee (CEC), which will decide on party strategy and organisation. Three key leadership roles will be the chair, vice chair, and spokesperson, but there will be 16 lay members of the CEC overall, who will represent regions within England. At a later date, more members will be elected to represent Wales and Scotland. And MPs will still have influence, as they will be able to sit in the public office holder section of the executive committee, as will local councillors. There will be four public office holder positions, and the CEC has the power to instruct those politicians to vote in line with party policy. This leadership model will be in place for at least a year, with a review to come in 2027. A Your Party spokesperson said: "This vote shows that we really are doing politics differently: from the bottom-up, not the top-down. "In Westminster, we have a professional political class increasingly disconnected from ordinary people, serving corporations and billionaires instead of the communities they are supposed to represent. "With a truly member-led party, we will offer something different: democratic, grassroots, accountable." Timeline for elections  The nominations will open in the new year, with final votes taking place at the end of February. In the meantime, Your Party will be led by the independent alliance (IA) of MPs and a randomly selected group of members, who will facilitate candidate selections for the local elections in May. The IA MPs involved in Your Party are Mr Corbyn, Shockat Adam and Ayoub Khan. Ms Sultana was previously part of the group but left a WhatsApp communications channel in September after launching an unauthorised membership portal and claiming she had been sidelined by a "sexist boys club" - sparking a major row that the party has struggled to recover from.  A source close to her denied quitting the IA, which has been stewarding the founding process, and claimed she had been excluded. They insisted Ms Sultana would be part of the caretaker leadership. Collective leadership is seen as a win for Ms Sultana's faction, as she had backed this over the single leadership model. Many grassroots groups also supported this option as they feel that unelected officials close to Mr Corbyn from his time as Labour leader have had too much say in what is going on behind the scenes. Infighting rumbles on  Your Party members have also voted to allow membership of other parties. Current rules don't permit dual membership, but this sparked a backlash on the eve of conference as it emerged figures from the Socialist Workers Party (SWP) had been expelled, while members of other left-wing groups were barred from entering the conference venue. Ms Sultana branded this a "witch hunt" orchestrated by faceless bureaucrats close to Mr Corbyn, and refused to enter the conference hall yesterday in protest. The vote on the leadership model and dual membership were ratified with a vote on the party's constitution and political statement this afternoon. This vote sparked some commotion as it emerged one group - the Democratic Socialists - initially urged its hundreds of members to vote against these documents despite supporting both the outcomes. Dem Soc said that although they have won victories, voting for the constitution would "validate" the "targeting of the organised left". That led to Ms Sultana, who has long been supported by Dem Soc, to warn that "certain people are looking to undermine the democratic vote that took place over the last 24 hours". Dem Soc later rescinded their advice, accusing the "Corbyn faction" of encouraging members to vote against the constitution and warning "the risk is now too great to prioritise principle and not pragmatism". Mr Corbyn had favoured a single leadership model and many of his allies argued Your Party had the best chance of succeeding if led by him, given his experience as Labour leader. His spokesperson said claims that his office were telling people to vote against the constitution are "completely false". He has not commented on the collective leadership vote, which Ms Sultana said was "truly exciting...and radically democratic." Your Party also voted on its official name, with members deciding to keep it as it is. The options on the shortlist included Our Party, Popular Alliance and For the Many - but Your Party won with 37% of the vote.

title: Lammy says justice reforms will reduce victims' suffering - as right to jury trial set to go in some cases
description: Victims will be put "front and centre" in reforms to be announced this week, Justice Secretary David Lammy has said, amid reports jury trials will be scrapped in some cases.
Author: Unknown
Headline: Shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick hits out at the expected changes, saying Britons shouldn't lose "ancient liberties", but Mr Lammy insists reforms are vital to deliver for victims and cut a huge crown court backlog.
Content:
Victims will be put "front and centre" in reforms to be announced this week, Justice Secretary David Lammy has said, amid reports jury trials will be scrapped in some cases. Sky News understands ministers have already been briefed on the changes, which would see a judge decide most cases on their own except for murder, rape or manslaughter - or those in the "public interest". The Ministry of Justice (MoJ) said the reforms would speed up justice and save victims from "years of torment and delay". Nearly 80,000 cases are currently waiting to be heard in crown courts, but a bid to limit the right to jury trial is likely to be divisive. Shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick said Mr Lammy should "pull his finger out" to cut the backlog rather than "depriving British citizens of ancient liberties". "The right to be tried by our peers has existed for more than 800 years - it is not to be casually discarded when the spreadsheets turn red," said Mr Jenrick. Full details are expected in the coming days, but in a statement on Sunday Mr Lammy said he had "inherited a courts emergency; a justice system pushed to the brink".

                 "We will not allow victims to suffer the way they did under the last government, we must put victims front and centre of the justice system," he added. Mr Lammy said thousands of lives were on hold due to the case backlog, a "rape victim being told their case won't come before a court until 2029. A mother who has lost a child at the hands of a dangerous driver, waiting to see justice done". He said he wanted a system that "finally gives brave survivors the justice they deserve". However, it's been reported Mr Lammy will go further than a review conducted by Sir Brian Leveson. The retired judge backed the move for juries only in the most serious cases, but also proposed some lesser offences could go to a new intermediate court where a judge would be joined by two lay magistrates. The Times said Mr Lammy had suggested in an internal memo he would remove the lay element from many serious offences that carry sentences of up to five years. There are fears such a move could increase miscarriages of justice and racial discrimination. The MoJ has laid the ground for the reforms by saying the court backlog could hit 100,000 by 2028 under the current system. It said just 3% of cases are currently decided by a jury, with more than 90% already dealt with by magistrates alone.

title: More than 600 dead in Indonesia and Thailand after floods and landslides - and Sri Lanka reporting more than 200 deaths from cyclone
description: The death toll following flooding and landslides in Indonesia and Thailand has risen to more than 600 - with nearby Sri Lanka also reporting more than 200 deaths after a cyclone.
Author: Unknown
Headline: A tropical storm that formed in the Malacca Strait has led to 435 deaths in Indonesia, 170 in southern Thailand, and three in Malaysia.
Content: The death toll following flooding and landslides in Indonesia and Thailand has risen to more than 600 - with nearby Sri Lanka also reporting more than 200 deaths after a cyclone. Three people have also died in Malaysia, officials have said, due to the extreme weather in South Asia and Southeast Asia. In total, Indonesian officials said 442 people had died and Thai authorities reported 170 deaths in the southern part of the country, as of midday UK time on Sunday. Rescue efforts were ongoing throughout the day, with more than four million people affected - almost three million in Southern Thailand and 1.1 million in Western Indonesia - by the effects of a tropical storm formed in the Malacca Strait. Indonesian relief and rescue teams have used helicopters to deliver aid to people they could not access because of blocked roads on the western island of Sumatra. Many areas have been cut off, while damage to telecommunications infrastructure has hampered communications. Officials said on Saturday that they had received reports of people looting supply lines as they grow desperate for relief in other areas. Hat Yai, the largest city in Thailand's Songkhla province, received 335mm (13 inches) of rain on Friday last week, its highest single-day tally in 300 years. After days of rain, meteorological authorities in Malaysia lifted tropical storm and continuous rain warnings there yesterday, forecasting clear skies for most of the country. However, there are still about 18,700 people in evacuation centres, according to the country's national disaster management agency. Another 218 people have been recorded as missing across the South Asian country's 25 districts, and more than half a million people have been affected nationwide.

title: British Independent Film Awards winners revealed
description: Biker romance Pillion has picked up the top prize at the British Independent Film Awards.
Author: Unknown
Headline: Pillion, The Ballad Of Wallis Island and My Father's Shadow were among the big winners at this year's BIFA ceremony in London.
Content: Biker romance Pillion has picked up the top prize at the British Independent Film Awards. The film's first-time feature writer and director Harry Lighton was also named best debut screenwriter at the ceremony, held at the Roundhouse in Camden, London, on Sunday evening. Starring Harry Melling as sweet and timid Colin, and Alexander Skarsgard as rugged biker Ray, the film picked up four prizes in total - including craft wins for best costume design and make-up and hair. Tom Basden and Tim Key took home the BIFA awards for best joint lead performance and best screenplay, for their debut feature The Ballad Of Wallis Island. Also starring Carey Mulligan, the film tells the story of a faded folk musician and his former partner who reluctantly reunite for an eccentric fan. Elsewhere in the acting categories, Robert Aramayo was honoured with the best lead performance award for his portrayal of Tourette's campaigner John Davison in I Swear, with the supporting performance award going to Jay Lycurgo for his role in pressure-cooker school drama Steve, also starring Oscar-winner Cillian Murphy. Newcomer Posy Sterling's portrayal of a mother fighting for custody of her children in Lollipop earned her the breakthrough performance award, while the best ensemble performance prize went to the cast of Warfare - including Will Poulter, Kit Connor, Joseph Quinn and Charles Melton. This year's ceremony also celebrated cinema itself, with the inaugural cinema of the year award going to The Magic Lantern Cinema in the Welsh coastal town of Tywyn. The BIFA for best international independent film was awarded to Sentimental Value, Joachim Trier's intimate exploration of family, memories and the reconciliatory power of art. Behind the camera, Akinola Davies Jr was named best director for his debut feature My Father's Shadow, a story of two brothers who first come to understand their father at a pivotal moment in both his life and Nigerian history, while The Douglas Hickox Award for best debut director went to Cal McMau for prison drama Wasteman. And in the documentary categories, Myrid Carten's exploration of mental health and addiction within her family, A Want In Her, picked up three BIFAs - best feature documentary, The Raindance Maverick Award, and best debut director for a feature documentary. Elsewhere, Emily Watson, star of films including Gosford Park, Punch-Drunk Love and War Horse, and TV series including Chernobyl and Dune: Prophecy, was awarded the outstanding contribution to British film prize. Production company Warp Films - behind films such as Dead Man's Shoes and This Is England, as well as the recent critically acclaimed series Adolescence - was honoured with the BIFA special jury prize for its "unflinching and uncompromising" commitment to telling "raw and relevant stories". Read more from Sky News entertainment:King pays tribute following death of Tom StoppardAI actress creator insists she's not out to steal jobs Founded in 1998, the BIFAs aim to celebrate, promote and support talent and creativity in British independent film. Previous winners of the best independent film award include Kneecap, the semi-autobiographical story of Irish-language rappers Kneecap, and Oscar winner The Favourite. This year's ceremony was hosted by comedians Lou Sanders and Harriet Kemsley, with Carey Mulligan, Stephen Merchant, Ruth Wilson, Billy Crudup and Celia Imrie among the star presenters.
